function.name: vse-converter-webservice

prototype.description: Web services often offer text analysis functions that can enrich your documents. This converter accesses web service functions via their REST API and adds the response to your document in a content which you may optionally post-process in your own custom converter.
prototype.label: Web Services

declare.name: ws-url
declare.label: Web Service endpoint URL
declare.description: The REST endpoint for the web service.

declare.name: ws-method
declare.label: HTTP Method
declare.description: The HTTP method used when fetching the web service REST URL. Note that limits on the size of POST data are typically greater than limits on the size of URLs (GET).

declare.name: ws-contents
declare.label: Contents to send as name/value pairs
declare.description:
Provide a newline-separated list of the names of contents whose names and values will be submitted as the parameter names and values in the web service call. For example, if you list
author
snippet
then the final web service call would include the following parameter name/value pairs
&author={content[@name="author"]/text()}
&snippet={content[@name="snippet"]/text()}
It is recommended that you configure a custom converter that is run before this one to pre-process your document's text into the appropriate contents.

declare.name: response-content
declare.label: Web Service response content name
declare.description:
Provide a string that will be used as the name of a new content output from this converter which contains the complete webservice response.
If necessary, you may create a new custom converter that is run after this one to further process the response. You may find viv:string-to-node() convenient for post-processing if the web service response is XML. See the Watson Explorer Engine XSL Extensions documentation for more information on this function.
Finally, consider whether it is appropriate to retain or discard any contents that were originally created only for the purpose of web service input, and handle them appropriately in your post-processing custom converter.

declare.name: ws-http-user
declare.label: HTTP Auth username
declare.description: Provide the HTTP authentication credentials used to authenticate to the web service URL if necessary.

declare.name: ws-http-pass
declare.label: HTTP Auth password
declare.description: Provide the HTTP authentication credentials used to authenticate to the web service URL if necessary.

declare.name: ws-proxy-host-port
declare.label: Proxy server (host:port)
declare.description: This sets a proxy server through which all web service calls will be directed. It is recommended that a local caching proxy be used to improve performance and reduce the total number of web service calls.

declare.name: ws-proxy-user-pass
declare.label: Proxy username and password
declare.description: Provide the credentials used to authenticate to the proxy server configured above.

declare.name: ws-timeout
declare.label: Timeout
declare.description: This sets the amount of time, in seconds, to wait for a response from the web service call.

declare.name: ws-headers
declare.label: Additional headers
declare.description:
Watson Explorer sends default HTTP headers. Provide here any additional HTTP headers to be sent with the request. Any header provided here which duplicates a default header will override the default header. Duplicate headers will not be sent. Use the common newline-separated HTTP header format:
Headername1: headervalue1
Headername2: headervalue2

declare.name: ws-ssl-cert
declare.label: SSL certificate location
declare.description: Full path to a file containing an SSL certificate to be used for HTTPS connections. This may or may not contain a private key.

declare.name: ws-ssl-key
declare.label: SSL private key location
declare.description:
Full path to a file containing an SSL private key to be used for HTTPS connections.
Note: If your certificate contains the private key, leave this blank.

declare.name: ws-ssl-key-type
declare.label: SSL private key type
declare.description:
Type of the SSL private key.
Note: If your certificate contains the private key, leave this blank.

declare.name: ws-ssl-key-pass
declare.label: SSL key (or cert) password
declare.description: Password used to read the private key file (or the certificate file when it contains the private key).

declare.name: ws-ssl-verify-peer
declare.label: Verify peer
declare.description: Determines whether Watson Explorer verifies the authenticity of the peer's certificate. When negotiating an SSL connection, the server sends a certificate indicating its identity. Watson Explorer verifies whether the certificate is authentic, i.e. that you can trust that the server is who the certificate says it is. This trust is based on a chain of digital signatures, rooted in certification authority (CA) certificates supplied in Engine/data/static/ca-bundle.crt

declare.name: ws-debug
declare.label: Enable debug contents
declare.description: If debug contents are enabled, contents containing details of the web service connection attempt will be added to the document. This is useful for debugging, but it may not be as valuable in your final crawl.
